title: Troubleshooting zigbee networks

transcript_segments.text: Right, so you want to know how to build a proper Zigbee network that actually works reliably,
or maybe you're doing battle with your current existing mesh network.
Either way, you're in the right place because today we're going to cover everything from
the absolute basics, like why your coordinates placement matters, all the way through to
numerating errors in your logs. We'll talk coordinators, routers versus end devices,
channel selection, interference, and yes, we'll even dive into log files which
often people tend to ignore but they play a key role in diagnosing a shins and building a
block solid setup. So as the video goes on, topics are going to get progressively more advanced.
Let's dive straight into the foundation, your coordinator. Now, I can't stress this enough.
The coordinators basically the brain of your entire Zigbee network.
Pick a rubbish one and you're going to be fighting connectivity issues for months.
Pick a good one and everything just works. Well, kind of. We'll get into that.
So when it comes to choosing a coordinator, do your research and I mean properly research it.
Don't just grab the first USB stick you find on Amazon because it's cheap. Read reviews,
check compatibility, look at the community forums. The few extra pounds that you spend here
is going to save you weeks of frustration later. What I'm using right now is the SLZB 06M.
I'll pop the link down in the description for that. It's actually not a USB stick.
It's a power over Ethernet coordinator and I absolutely love it. I would highly recommend them.
It's been absolutely rock solid for me and the range is fantastic but here's the thing. Even if
you've got the best coordinator in the world, placement matters more than you might think. We'll
cover that a little bit more later on in the video. If you're using a USB coordinator and there's
lots of people out there who are, you absolutely need to use a USB extension cable. Why? Because
USB 3 ports can cause electromagnetic interference through your Zigbee channel. This isn't some
theoretical problem either. It's actually real. There's a really good video that was demonstrated by
the people at Nabakaza who show that moving USB cable closer to a coordinator actually stops it
from working. This is the sort of thing that will drive you absolutely mad, trying to figure out
why your devices keep on dropping off line and it's going to be very erratic and difficult to
troubleshoot. So definitely make sure that you're using a shielded extension cable. A simple
extension cable costs next to nothing and it can literally save your entire network. Get the
USB 3 ports and ideally somewhere central in your home. Think about your home's layout. Where
are the devices actually going to be and what's going to be between them. A central location on
the ground floor might not help much if half of your devices are upstairs. In the middle of your
house is surrounded by solid walls then considered at 2.4 gigahertz signals might not travel through them
particularly well. Now here's something that catches a lot of people out. Connecting directly to your
coordinator might seem fast and like a good idea but be aware there is a device limit on coordinators.
You should check the documentation exactly for what the device limit is on your coordinator.
This is generally okay when you're just starting out in your Zigbee network and you've got a handful
of devices on them but if you get the bug and you end up with 80 devices on your network
you'll start to see problems. What you're ultimately aiming for is a mesh network. Right let's
talk about something that will save you massive headaches if you get it right from the start which
is channel selection. Zigbee works on 2.4 gigahertz which is the same frequency as your Wi-Fi,
your microwave and half the electronics in your house. The key is finding the channel doesn't clash
with everything else. Use an app like Wi-Fi analyzer. Again there's a link down in the description to
check what channels you're surrounding 2.4 gigahertz Wi-Fi they're using. You want to pick a Zigbee
channel that's far away from busy Wi-Fi channel as possible. Here's the critical bit. Make the
decision at the start. If you change your Zigbee channel later you'll have to repair every single
device in your network and trust me you don't want to have to do that with 50 plus devices.
Now let's get into the integrity of how the network actually works. You've got three types of
devices. You've got your coordinator which we've covered and you've also got routers and end
devices. Understanding the difference is crucial for a reliable network. Routers are typically
devices that have constant power so your smart plugs, your light switches, your smart bulbs.
Be careful though because not all powered devices are routers. You should definitely check the
documentation for that and it's a dangerous assumption to make that all powered devices will be
routers. Some manufacturers make mains powered devices that only act as end devices which is pretty
useless for building a strong mesh network. I got caught out here by buying some of the Eukara H1
light switches assuming that they would work as routers. End devices are your battery powered
sensors like motion sensors, door sensors, temperature sensors, that kind of stuff. These little guys
don't route traffic like other devices. They just connect your network and send their data but they
won't route packets to other devices. Typically devices can connect to any router in range. Some
bit can be quite picky about which routers they connect to though. If you try and pair your device
in their final position that tends to help with the routing. Don't pair them next to your
coordinator and then move them across the house. They'll try and maintain the original connection
even if there's a better route nearby. Now the mesh itself is where ZigBee gets really clever.
ZigBee devices form their mesh automatically. It sounds great and furry. There's something that
most people don't realise though. It takes time and I'm not just talking hours or even days but
some ZigBee networks can take weeks to establish themselves so that they're fully optimised.
This is probably the hardest part for most people because everyone wants things to work perfectly
right away but your devices are constantly learning about each other and figuring out the best
routes and adapting changes in their environment. Patience is absolutely key here.
Something that may well save you hours of troubleshooting is knowing that some devices are
what I call sticky so a car or devices in the tourist for this. They latch onto the first
router they connect to and they're refused to jump to a better router even if the signal strength
is terrible. That's why pairing in the final position for these kind of devices is especially
important. Don't overload routers either. They have limits on how many devices they can handle
typically. The good news is you can actually pair and devices with specific routers if you know what
you're doing. I use ZigBee to MQTT and there's an option to open up pairing on the network for
specific devices so I highly encourage trying that out. Okay this is what separates the beginners from
the advanced users is deep diving into log files. Most people will tend to ignore their logs but
the logs are basically telling me a story about what's happening on your network and trust me once
you know how to read them troubleshooting becomes so much more easy. Okay so here we have the entire
database with all of the ZigBee devices in. We've got the configuration which will basically give us
a mapping of those ZigBee devices over to a friendly name and we have the log file which is where all
the fun things are happening. So if we look at the root error many to one failures and we look at
this as an example of one of the things that's going wrong. You can see it happens quite a lot
throughout the logs and this is one of the things that we wanted to dive into but there is all of
these log file instances and we don't really want to go through and manually figure out how often
this is happening. So what we're going to do is take the log file and we're going to use the

it's this particular manufacturing device or device with this manufacturing name it's going to give

which happens a lot for this particular ID all the way back to the snug LED Vance socket. So I don't

What I've done is I've uploaded a bunch of some of the old log files and the old configurations
so you can see it before and after and I've taken basically this prompt and I've said using the old
logs the old configurations and the old database find this particular error and various other errors
and then go through and basically do all of that mapping so we can figure out what it looks like.
It's going to go through and do its magic and we're basically going to get this artifact and it's
going to tell us what the friendly name is the i-triple address and basically the errors and
how critical those errors are, how often they're occurring in the logs and stuff like that.
So you can leverage this quite easily to figure out what's going on with your network.
I also used, I'll go back to my network, the newer version after I've basically gone through and
fixed a bunch of my issues and I ran the same analysis and basically got a similar result
but you can see here the numbers are much lower. There's basically only some very very low
severity errors. Some of them were actually due to things like configuration timeouts and
Claude's going to be very useful here and basically tell me this is basically not much an issue.
It's a fairly transient issue that happens during startup and it's going to tell me a few
recommendations and in conclusion the cleanup was highly successful, brilliant. So I'm still going
to use the logs and I'm going to look through the logs to get some hints on what I might be looking
for and then I'm just going to use AI to help me enumerate those instances and figure out what needs to
happen next. Look, building a reliable Zigbee network isn't rocket science but it does require
a bit of patience and understanding on how these devices actually work together.
Start with a coordinator, choose your channels carefully, understand the difference between

sections.title: Troubleshooting ZigBee Networks: A Comprehensive Guide to Building a Reliable Smart Home Mesh
sections.content: To build a proper ZigBee network that operates reliably, or to effectively troubleshoot an existing mesh, understanding its fundamental components and common pitfalls is essential. This guide covers everything from the absolute basics, such as the critical importance of coordinator placement, to advanced techniques like enumerating errors within your system logs. We will delve into coordinators, the distinctions between routers and end devices, optimal channel selection, interference mitigation, and the often-overlooked but crucial role of log files. These logs are key to diagnosing issues and establishing a robust, rock-solid setup. As we progress, the topics will become progressively more advanced, providing a comprehensive understanding for both beginners and experienced users.

paragraphs.content: To build a proper ZigBee network that operates reliably, or to effectively troubleshoot an existing mesh, understanding its fundamental components and common pitfalls is essential. This guide covers everything from the absolute basics, such as the critical importance of coordinator placement, to advanced techniques like enumerating errors within your system logs. We will delve into coordinators, the distinctions between routers and end devices, optimal channel selection, interference mitigation, and the often-overlooked but crucial role of log files. These logs are key to diagnosing issues and establishing a robust, rock-solid setup. As we progress, the topics will become progressively more advanced, providing a comprehensive understanding for both beginners and experienced users.

sections.title: The Coordinator: The Brain of Your Network
sections.content:
Let's begin with the foundation: your coordinator. It cannot be stressed enough that the coordinator functions as the central intelligence of your entire ZigBee network. Selecting an inadequate coordinator will inevitably lead to persistent connectivity issues. Conversely, choosing a high-quality coordinator significantly enhances network stability, though other factors also play a role.
When selecting a coordinator, thorough research is paramount. Avoid simply purchasing the cheapest USB stick available; instead, consult reviews, verify compatibility, and explore community forums. The modest additional investment here can prevent weeks of frustration later. Currently, the SLZB 06M is a highly recommended option. This device is not a USB stick but a Power over Ethernet (PoE) coordinator, offering exceptional reliability and range.
Even with the best coordinator, placement is more critical than often perceived. This aspect will be explored further in this guide. If you are utilizing a USB coordinator, which many users do, employing a USB extension cable is absolutely essential. This is because USB 3 ports can generate electromagnetic interference (EMI) that disrupts your ZigBee channel. This is not a theoretical concern; it has been demonstrably shown that moving a USB cable closer to a coordinator can cause it to cease functioning. Such erratic and difficult-to-troubleshoot issues can be incredibly frustrating, leading to devices intermittently dropping offline. Therefore, always ensure you use a shielded USB extension cable. A simple, inexpensive extension cable can literally safeguard your entire network.
Position your coordinator away from USB 3 ports and, ideally, in a central location within your home. Consider your home's layout: where are the devices located, and what physical obstructions (e.g., walls) exist between them? A central ground-floor location may not be optimal if a significant portion of your devices are upstairs. If the coordinator is situated in the middle of your house but surrounded by solid walls, remember that 2.4 GHz signals may not penetrate them effectively.
A common misconception is that connecting devices directly to the coordinator is always the best approach. While seemingly fast, coordinators have a finite device limit, which should be verified in the device's documentation. This limitation is generally not an issue when initially setting up a small ZigBee network with a few devices. However, as your network expands to 80 or more devices, you will likely encounter performance problems. The ultimate goal is to establish a robust mesh network.

sections.title: Critical Channel Selection
sections.content:
Proper channel selection can prevent significant headaches from the outset. ZigBee operates on the 2.4 GHz frequency, which is shared with Wi-Fi, microwave ovens, and numerous other household electronics. The key is to identify a ZigBee channel that minimizes interference with these other devices. Utilize a tool like Wi-Fi Analyzer (links available in the description) to identify the 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi channels in your surrounding environment. Your objective is to select a ZigBee channel that is as far as possible from busy Wi-Fi channels.
This decision is critical and must be made early. Changing your ZigBee channel later will necessitate re-pairing every single device in your network. With 50 or more devices, this is an extremely time-consuming and undesirable task.

ZigBee operates on the 2.4 GHz frequency, which is shared with Wi-Fi, microwave ovens, and numerous other household electronics. The key is to identify a ZigBee channel that minimizes interference with these other devices. Utilize a tool like Wi-Fi Analyzer (links available in the description) to identify the 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi channels in your surrounding environment. Your objective is to select a ZigBee channel that is as far as possible from busy Wi-Fi channels.
This decision is critical and must be made early. Changing your ZigBee channel later will necessitate re-pairing every single device in your network. With 50 or more devices, this is an extremely time-consuming and undesirable task.

sections.title: Understanding ZigBee Device Types
sections.content:
To comprehend the integrity of your network, it's crucial to distinguish between the three types of ZigBee devices: the coordinator (already discussed), routers, and end devices. Understanding their roles is fundamental for building a reliable network.
**Routers** are typically devices that receive constant power, such as smart plugs, light switches, and smart bulbs. However, it is vital to note that not all powered devices function as routers. Always consult the device's documentation, as assuming all mains-powered devices are routers can be a dangerous oversight. Some manufacturers produce mains-powered devices that only act as end devices, which significantly limits their utility in building a strong mesh network. A common pitfall, which I personally encountered, involves certain mains-powered devices, such as the Aqara H1 light switches, that do not function as routers despite being powered.
**End devices** are generally battery-powered sensors, including motion sensors, door sensors, and temperature sensors. These devices do not route traffic for other devices; they simply connect to the network and transmit their own data.
While devices typically connect to any router within range, some can be quite particular about which routers they choose. Pairing devices in their final intended position often improves routing efficiency. Avoid pairing devices directly next to your coordinator and then relocating them across the house, as they may attempt to maintain the original, less optimal connection even when a better route is available nearby.

paragraphs.content:
To comprehend the integrity of your network, it's crucial to distinguish between the three types of ZigBee devices: the coordinator (already discussed), routers, and end devices. Understanding their roles is fundamental for building a reliable network.
**Routers** are typically devices that receive constant power, such as smart plugs, light switches, and smart bulbs. However, it is vital to note that not all powered devices function as routers. Always consult the device's documentation, as assuming all mains-powered devices are routers can be a dangerous oversight. Some manufacturers produce mains-powered devices that only act as end devices, which significantly limits their utility in building a strong mesh network. A common pitfall, which I personally encountered, involves certain mains-powered devices, such as the Aqara H1 light switches, that do not function as routers despite being powered.
**End devices** are generally battery-powered sensors, including motion sensors, door sensors, and temperature sensors. These devices do not route traffic for other devices; they simply connect to the network and transmit their own data.
While devices typically connect to any router within range, some can be quite particular about which routers they choose. Pairing devices in their final intended position often improves routing efficiency. Avoid pairing devices directly next to your coordinator and then relocating them across the house, as they may attempt to maintain the original, less optimal connection even when a better route is available nearby.

sections.title: The ZigBee Mesh Network: Patience is Key
sections.content:
The mesh network is where ZigBee's intelligence truly shines. ZigBee devices automatically form their mesh, which sounds ideal. However, a crucial aspect often overlooked is the time it takes for this mesh to fully establish and optimize itself. This process can take not just hours or days, but sometimes weeks for a ZigBee network to become fully stable and efficient. This waiting period is often the most challenging for users, as there's an expectation for immediate perfect functionality. Yet, your devices are continuously learning about each other, identifying optimal routes, and adapting to environmental changes. Patience is absolutely critical here.
A common troubleshooting challenge arises from what are termed "sticky" devices, with Aqara devices being a notable example. These devices tend to latch onto the first router they connect to and may refuse to switch to a better router, even if the signal strength is poor. For such devices, pairing them in their final operational position is especially important.
Furthermore, avoid overloading individual routers, as they have limits on the number of devices they can handle. The good news is that it is possible to pair end devices with specific routers if you possess the necessary knowledge. For advanced control, platforms like Zigbee2MQTT offer functionality to initiate pairing for specific devices, which is a highly recommended approach.

sections.title: Advanced Troubleshooting: Deep Diving into Log Files
sections.content:
Mastering log file analysis is what distinguishes beginners from advanced users. While many users tend to ignore their logs, these files narrate the precise events occurring within your network. Once you learn to interpret them, troubleshooting becomes significantly easier.
The system comprises a comprehensive database of ZigBee devices, a configuration file mapping these devices to user-friendly names, and a crucial log file detailing network events. For instance, examining a recurring error like "root error many to one failures" within the logs reveals its frequent occurrence. Manually sifting through numerous log instances to quantify this is impractical.
To analyze specific errors, the process involves extracting the device ID from the log file. This ID, often an IEEE address, can then be cross-referenced with the device database to identify the specific manufacturer and friendly name, for instance, the "snug LED Vance socket," thereby linking recurring errors to their source.
Automating this analysis is highly efficient. For example, leveraging an AI tool like Claude, as demonstrated, allows for rapid processing of log files. By uploading historical log files and configurations, a prompt can be used to instruct the AI to identify specific errors and perform all necessary mapping. The AI then processes the data, generating an artifact that details the friendly name, IEEE address, error types, and their criticality and frequency within the logs. This capability allows for easy identification of network issues.
Subsequent analysis of the network, after implementing corrective measures, revealed a significant reduction in error frequency and severity, with only minor, low-severity issues remaining. Some of these minor errors, such as configuration timeouts, are often transient issues occurring during startup, which AI tools can help classify as non-critical. The cleanup process, as confirmed by the analysis, was highly successful.
Therefore, while manually reviewing logs provides initial hints, leveraging AI tools to enumerate instances and identify next steps significantly streamlines the troubleshooting process.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content:
Building a reliable ZigBee network is not overly complex, but it does demand patience and a foundational understanding of how these devices interact. Begin with a well-chosen coordinator, meticulously select your channels, comprehend the distinctions between routers and end devices, and, most importantly, regularly review your system logs. Adhering to these principles will result in an incredibly reliable, responsive, and seamlessly functioning smart home network. Neglecting these steps, however, will lead to constant connectivity battles and a smart home that feels anything but intelligent.
If this guide has been helpful, please consider supporting the content. Check the description for links to mentioned tools and resources. Share your biggest ZigBee challenges or any insights you believe were missed in the comments below. Your feedback is invaluable and often inspires future content. Until next time, happy automating!

To build a proper ZigBee network that operates reliably, or to effectively troubleshoot an existing mesh, understanding its fundamental components and common pitfalls is essential. This guide covers everything from the absolute basics, such as the critical importance of coordinator placement, to advanced techniques like enumerating errors within your system logs. These logs are key to diagnosing issues and establishing a robust, rock-solid setup. As we progress, the topics will become progressively more advanced, providing a comprehensive understanding for both beginners and experienced users.

## The Coordinator: The Brain of Your Network

Let's begin with the foundation: your coordinator. It cannot be stressed enough that the coordinator functions as the central intelligence of your entire ZigBee network. Selecting an inadequate coordinator will inevitably lead to persistent connectivity issues. Conversely, choosing a high-quality coordinator significantly enhances network stability, though other factors also play a role.

When selecting a coordinator, thorough research is paramount. Avoid simply purchasing the cheapest USB stick available; instead, consult reviews, verify compatibility, and explore community forums. The modest additional investment here can prevent weeks of frustration later. Currently, the SLZB 06M is a highly recommended option. Even with the best coordinator, placement is more critical than often perceived. This aspect will be explored further in this guide. If you are utilizing a USB coordinator, which many users do, employing a USB extension cable is absolutely essential. This is because USB 3 ports can generate electromagnetic interference (EMI) that disrupts your ZigBee channel. This is not a theoretical concern; it has been demonstrably shown that moving a USB cable closer to a coordinator can cause it to cease functioning. Such erratic and difficult-to-troubleshoot issues can be incredibly frustrating, leading to devices intermittently dropping offline. Therefore, always ensure you use a shielded USB extension cable. A simple, inexpensive extension cable can literally safeguard your entire network.

Position your coordinator away from USB 3 ports and, ideally, in a central location within your home. Consider your home's layout: where are the devices located, and what physical obstructions (e.g., walls) exist between them? A central ground-floor location may not be optimal if a significant portion of your devices are upstairs. If the coordinator is situated in the middle of your house but surrounded by solid walls, remember that 2.4 GHz signals may not penetrate them effectively.

A common misconception is that connecting devices directly to the coordinator is always the best approach. This limitation is generally not an issue when initially setting up a small ZigBee network with a few devices. However, as your network expands to 80 or more devices, you will likely encounter performance problems. The ultimate goal is to establish a robust mesh network.

## Critical Channel Selection

Proper channel selection can prevent significant headaches from the outset. ZigBee operates on the 2.4 GHz frequency, which is shared with Wi-Fi, microwave ovens, and numerous other household electronics. The key is to identify a ZigBee channel that minimizes interference with these other devices. Utilize a tool like Wi-Fi Analyzer (links available in the description) to identify the 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi channels in your surrounding environment. Your objective is to select a ZigBee channel that is as far as possible from busy Wi-Fi channels.

This decision is critical and must be made early. Changing your ZigBee channel later will necessitate re-pairing every single device in your network. With 50 or more devices, this is an extremely time-consuming and undesirable task.

## Understanding ZigBee Device Types

To comprehend the integrity of your network, it's crucial to distinguish between the three types of ZigBee devices: the coordinator (already discussed), routers, and end devices. Understanding their roles is fundamental for building a reliable network.

**Routers** are typically devices that receive constant power, such as smart plugs, light switches, and smart bulbs. However, it is vital to note that not all powered devices function as routers. Always consult the device's documentation, as assuming all mains-powered devices are routers can be a dangerous oversight. Some manufacturers produce mains-powered devices that only act as end devices, which significantly limits their utility in building a strong mesh network. A common pitfall, which I personally encountered, involves certain mains-powered devices, such as the Aqara H1 light switches, that do not function as routers despite being powered.

**End devices** are generally battery-powered sensors, including motion sensors, door sensors, and temperature sensors. These devices do not route traffic for other devices; they simply connect to the network and transmit their own data.

While devices typically connect to any router within range, some can be quite particular about which routers they choose. Pairing devices in their final intended position often improves routing efficiency. Avoid pairing devices directly next to your coordinator and then relocating them across the house, as they may attempt to maintain the original, less optimal connection even when a better route is available nearby.

## The ZigBee Mesh Network: Patience is Key

The mesh network is where ZigBee's intelligence truly shines. ZigBee devices automatically form their mesh, which sounds ideal. However, a crucial aspect often overlooked is the time it takes for this mesh to fully establish and optimize itself. This process can take not just hours or days, but sometimes weeks for a ZigBee network to become fully stable and efficient. This waiting period is often the most challenging for users, as there's an expectation for immediate perfect functionality. Yet, your devices are continuously learning about each other, identifying optimal routes, and adapting to environmental changes. Patience is absolutely critical here.

A common troubleshooting challenge arises from what are termed "sticky" devices, with Aqara devices being a notable example. These devices tend to latch onto the first router they connect to and may refuse to switch to a better router, even if the signal strength is poor. For such devices, pairing them in their final operational position is especially important.

Furthermore, avoid overloading individual routers, as they have limits on the number of devices they can handle. The good news is that it is possible to pair end devices with specific routers if you possess the necessary knowledge. For advanced control, platforms like Zigbee2MQTT offer functionality to initiate pairing for specific devices, which is a highly recommended approach.

## Advanced Troubleshooting: Deep Diving into Log Files

Mastering log file analysis is what distinguishes beginners from advanced users. While many users tend to ignore their logs, these files narrate the precise events occurring within your network. Once you learn to interpret them, troubleshooting becomes significantly easier.

The system comprises a comprehensive database of ZigBee devices, a configuration file mapping these devices to user-friendly names, and a crucial log file detailing network events. For instance, examining a recurring error like "root error many to one failures" within the logs reveals its frequent occurrence. Manually sifting through numerous log instances to quantify this is impractical.

To analyze specific errors, the process involves extracting the device ID from the log file. This ID, often an IEEE address, can then be cross-referenced with the device database to identify the specific manufacturer and friendly name, for instance, the "snug LED Vance socket," thereby linking recurring errors to their source.

Automating this analysis is highly efficient. For example, leveraging an AI tool like Claude, as demonstrated, allows for rapid processing of log files. By uploading historical log files and configurations, a prompt can be used to instruct the AI to identify specific errors and perform all necessary mapping. The AI then processes the data, generating an artifact that details the friendly name, IEEE address, error types, and their criticality and frequency within the logs. This capability allows for easy identification of network issues.

Subsequent analysis of the network, after implementing corrective measures, revealed a significant reduction in error frequency and severity, with only minor, low-severity issues remaining. Some of these minor errors, such as configuration timeouts, are often transient issues occurring during startup, which AI tools can help classify as non-critical. The cleanup process, as confirmed by the analysis, was highly successful.

Therefore, while manually reviewing logs provides initial hints, leveraging AI tools to enumerate instances and identify next steps significantly streamlines the troubleshooting process.

## Conclusion

Building a reliable ZigBee network is not overly complex, but it does demand patience and a foundational understanding of how these devices interact. Begin with a well-chosen coordinator, meticulously select your channels, comprehend the distinctions between routers and end devices, and, most importantly, regularly review your system logs. Adhering to these principles will result in an incredibly reliable, responsive, and seamlessly functioning smart home network. Neglecting these steps, however, will lead to constant connectivity battles and a smart home that feels anything but intelligent.
